revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=May 2012}} {{Infobox person | name = Jean Dujardin | image = Jean Dujardin Césars 2017 (cropped).jpg | caption = Jean Dujardin in 2017 | birthname = | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1972|6|19|df=y}} | birth_place = [[Rueil-Malmaison]], France | occupation = {{Flatlist| * Actor * television director * comedian }} | yearsactive = 1996–present | spouse = Gaëlle Dujardin (?–2003)
{{marriage|[[Alexandra Lamy]]|25 July 2009|reason=divorced|December 2014}}{{cite web|url=http://tvmag.lefigaro.fr/programme-tv/article/television/84952/alexandra-lamy-et-jean-dujardin-officiellement-divorces-.html|title=Alexandra Lamy et Jean Dujardin officiellement divorcés|publisher=Le Figaro|date=25 December 2014|accessdate=23 October 2016}} | children = 3 }} '''Jean Dujardin''' ({{IPA-fr|ʒɑ̃ dy.ʒaʁ.dɛ̃|-|Fr-Jean Dujardin.ogg}}; born 19 June 1972) is a French actor, television director and humorist. He began his career as a [[Stand-up comedy|stand-up comedian]] in Paris before starting his acting career guest-starring in comedic television programs and films. He first came to prominence with the [[cult]] TV series ''[[Un gars, une fille (French TV series)|Un gars, une fille]]'', in which he starred alongside his lover [[Alexandra Lamy]], before gaining success in film with movies such as ''[[Brice de Nice]]'', [[Michel Hazanavicius]]'s ''[[OSS 117: Cairo, Nest of Spies]]'' and its sequel ''[[OSS 117: Lost in Rio]]'', and ''[[99 Francs (film)|99 Francs]]''. Dujardin garnered international fame and widespread acclaim with his performance of George Valentin in the 2011 award-winning [[silent film|silent]] movie ''[[The Artist (film)|The Artist]]''. The role won him numerous awards, including the [[Academy Award for Best Actor]] (the first for a French actor), the [[Golden Globe Award for Best Actor – Motion Picture Musical or Comedy]], the [[BAFTA Award for Best Actor in a Leading Role]], the [[Screen Actors Guild Award for Outstanding Performance by a Male Actor in a Leading Role]] and the [[Best Actor Award (Cannes Film Festival)|Cannes Film Festival Best Actor]]. He later appeared in [[Martin Scorsese]]'s 2013 black comedy ''[[The Wolf of Wall Street (2013 film)|The Wolf of Wall Street]]'' and [[George Clooney]]'s 2014 historical drama, ''[[The Monuments Men]]''. ==Early life== Jean Dujardin was born on 19 June 1972 and raised in [[Rueil-Malmaison]] ([[Hauts-de-Seine]], [[Île-de-France]] region), a [[Communes of France|commune]] in the western suburbs of [[Paris|Paris, France]].{{cite web |title=Jean Dujardin: Biography, Latest News & Videos |url=http://www.tvguide.com/celebrities/jean-dujardin/293684 |work=[[TV Guide]] |accessdate=20 January 2012}} After attending high school, he went to work for the construction company of his father, Jacques Dujardin.{{cite web |title=Golden Globes: Jean Dujardin wins best actor in a comedy or musical |url=http://latimesblogs.latimes.com/movies/2012/01/golden-globes-best-actor-comedy-musical.html |work=Los Angeles Times |accessdate=20 January 2012}}{{cite news|title=Jean Dujardin, un gars dans les étoiles|url=http://www.lemonde.fr/cinema/article/2012/02/27/jean-dujardin-un-gars-dans-les-etoiles_1648737_3476.html|accessdate=13 November 2013}} Dujardin began contemplating a career in acting while serving his mandatory military service a few years later. ==Career== Dujardin began his acting career performing a one-man show he wrote in various bars and cabarets in Paris. He first gained attention when he appeared on the French talent show ''Graines de star'' in 1996 as part of the comedy group ''Nous Ç Nous'', which was formed by members of the ''Carré blanc'' theater. From 1999 to 2003, Dujardin starred in the France production of the originally Canadian comedy series ''[[Un gars, une fille]]'', alongside his future wife [[Alexandra Lamy]], before transitioning to a career in film. The TV series charted the path of a relationship; each episode was less than ten minutes long. In 2005, he portrayed the titular surfer in the popular comedic film ''[[Brice de Nice]]'' and performed on its accompanying soundtrack.{{citation needed|date=May 2015}} In 2006, Dujardin starred as racist, sexist secret agent [[Hubert Bonisseur de La Bath]] in the comedy ''[[OSS 117: Cairo, Nest of Spies]]'', a role which earned him an Etoile D'Or Award and a [[César Award]] nomination for [[César Award for Best Actor|Best Actor]]. The film's success spawned a sequel, ''[[OSS 117: Lost in Rio]]''. In 2007, directed by [[Jan Kounen]], he starred in the film ''[[99 Francs (film)|99F (99 francs)]]'', a very successful existential parody of an advertising exec, adapted from the eponymous best-seller written by [[Frédéric Beigbeder]]. This same year, he ventured in drama for the first time on the silver screen, playing a tortured father and cop in Franck Mancuso's ''[[Contre-enquête]]''. In 2009, he appeared in ''[[A Man and His Dog]]'' alongside screen legend [[Jean-Paul Belmondo]], with whom he has often been compared. In 2010, he starred alongside [[Albert Dupontel]], playing his character's cancer in ''[[The Clink of Ice]]'', a French black comedy written and directed by [[Bertrand Blier]]. [[File:Raimu01.JPG|thumb|left|Jean Dujardin with [[Charlotte Gainsbourg]] in 2011]] In 2011, Dujardin starred as movie star George Valentin in the [[silent film]] ''[[The Artist (film)|The Artist]]'', reuniting him with ''OSS 117: Cairo, Nest of Spies'' director [[Michel Hazanavicius]] and his co-star in that film, [[Bérénice Bejo]]. The film premiered at the 2011 [[Cannes Film Festival]], where he received the [[Best Actor Award (Cannes Film Festival)|Best Actor Award]].[https://www.google.com/hostednews/afp/article/ALeqM5hPRrHWUGZPp4c5Z-DoCH0esekXQQ?docId=CNG.076f1f6447aa97c29bac5277c2a3c00e.9f1 AFP: Jean Dujardin: one of France's most bankable stars]. Google.com (22 May 2011);retrieved 4 July 2011. {{Dead link |date=January 2017}} His performance garnered much critical acclaim and he received numerous nominations, including the [[Broadcast Film Critics Association Award for Best Actor]] and the [[Screen Actors Guild Award for Outstanding Performance by a Male Actor in a Leading Role|Screen Actors Guild for Best Actor]]. On 15 January 2012, Dujardin won a [[Golden Globe Award for Best Actor – Motion Picture Musical or Comedy]].{{cite web|last=Kaufman|first=Amy|title=Golden Globes: Jean Dujardin wins best actor in a comedy or musical|url=http://latimesblogs.latimes.com/movies/2012/01/golden-globes-best-actor-comedy-musical.html|work=Los Angeles Times|accessdate=17 January 2012|date=15 January 2012}} He later went on to win the [[Screen Actors Guild Award for Outstanding Performance by a Male Actor in a Leading Role|Screen Actors Guild for Best Actor]], and the [[BAFTA Award for Best Actor in a Leading Role|BAFTA for Best Actor]]. He was also nominated for the [[César award]] of the best actor but lost it to ''[[Omar Sy]]'' for his role in the second most ever viewed movie in France ''[[Intouchables]]''. Dujardin went on to win the Best Actor award at the [[84th Academy Awards]].{{cite web|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10001424052970203833004577247652268602514|title=The Artist Wins Big as Oscar Romances Past|date=27 February 2012|work=Wall Street Journal|accessdate=1 March 2012}} In effect he is the fourth French actor to be nominated for an [[Academy Award|Oscar]] and the first to win the [[Academy Award for Best Actor|Best Actor]].{{cite news|title=Oscars: Live Report |url=https://www.google.com/hostednews/afp/article/ALeqM5hU3KILNhkwaGjC3Oesvw3reUIigQ?docId=CNG.4162445dbe6d927e6b56d44aebf135a3.191 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120301002834/http://www.google.com/hostednews/afp/article/ALeqM5hU3KILNhkwaGjC3Oesvw3reUIigQ?docId=CNG.4162445dbe6d927e6b56d44aebf135a3.191 |dead-url=yes |archive-date= 1 March 2012 |agency=AFP |accessdate=27 February 2012 |date=26 February 2012 |df= }} He has been described as France's answer to [[George Clooney]].{{cite news| url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/tvshowbiz/article-2087276/Golden-Globes-2012-The-Artists-Jean-Dujardin-French-George-Clooney-wows-critics.html|work=Daily Mail |location=UK|title=George who? The 'French Clooney' Jean Dujardin takes home a Golden Globe as he continues to wow critics with The Artist|date=16 January 2012|accessdate=3 February 2012|first1=Sarah|last1=Bull}} Following his Oscar nomination for his role in ''The Artist'', [[WME (talent agency)|WME]] agency signed the actor.{{cite web|title=WME Signs 'The Artist' Actor Jean Dujardin (Exclusive)|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/risky-business/wme-signs-artist-actor-jean-286093|work=[[The Hollywood Reporter]]|accessdate=27 February 2012|author=Jay A. Fernandez|author2=Borys Kit|date=31 January 2012}} French film historian Tim Palmer has analyzed Dujardin's career and rise to success in France, noting how his formative roles were often unredeemable buffoons, very skillful portrayals of childlike men who aggressively and unabashedly reject the responsibilities and compromises of adult life. Dujardin's breakthrough roles as Brice de Nice and OSS 117 exemplified this tendency.Palmer, Tim (2011). ''Brutal Intimacy: Analyzing Contemporary French Cinema'', Wesleyan University Press, Middleton CT. {{ISBN|0-8195-6827-9}}. In February 2012, Dujardin appeared in ''[[The Players (film)|Les Infidèles]]'' with co-star and friend [[Gilles Lellouche]]. He was invited to join the [[Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences]] in June 2012 along with 175 other individuals.{{cite web|url=http://www.oscars.org/press/pressreleases/2012/20120629a.html|title=Academy Invites 176 to Membership|publisher=The Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences|date=29 June 2012|accessdate=19 July 2013}} In 2013, Dujardin starred in [[Éric Rochant]]'s ''[[Möbius (film)|Möbius]]'' with [[Cécile de France]] and [[Tim Roth]].{{cite web|last=Goldberg|first=Matt|title=Jean Dujardin and Cecile de France to Star in Romantic Thriller MOBIUS|url=http://collider.com/jean-dujardin-cecile-de-france-mobius/125390|work=Collider|accessdate=27 February 2012|date=8 November 2011}} [[Image:Jean Dujardin 2014.jpg|thumb|upright=0.75|Jean Dujardin in 2014]] His second film that year was [[Martin Scorsese]]'s ''[[The Wolf of Wall Street (2013 film)|The Wolf of Wall Street]]'', playing alongside [[Leonardo DiCaprio]], [[Jonah Hill]], [[Matthew McConaughey]], and [[Kyle Chandler]], among others.{{cite web|last=Miller|first=Daniel|title=Jean Dujardin in Talks to Join Martin Scorsese's 'The Wolf of Wall Street'|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/jean-dujardin-martin-scorsese-wolf-of-wall-street-337876|work=The Hollywood Reporter|accessdate=19 July 2013|date=14 June 2012}} He appeared in ''[[The Monuments Men]]'', directed by [[George Clooney]], and co-starring Clooney, [[Matt Damon]], and [[Cate Blanchett]],{{cite web|title=George Clooney's 'The Monuments Men' Eyeing Jean Dujardin (Exclusive)|url=http://www.thewrap.com/movies/column-post/jean-dujardin-possible-monuments-men-exclusive-58821|work=The Wrap|accessdate=19 July 2013|date=2 October 2012}} and starred in the French film ''Le Petit Joueur''.{{cite web|title=Jean Dujardin May Head Back to His Roots in 'Le Petit Joueur'|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/jean-dujardin-le-petit-joueur-295677|work=The Hollywood Reporter|accessdate=19 July 2013|date=28 February 2012}} In late 2014, ''[[La French]]'', was released in Europe and subsequently in the United States in early 2015. He plays a French police magistrate who tries to dismantle the [[French Connection]] and bring down the [[Unione Corse]].{{citation needed|date=May 2015}} ==Personal life== Dujardin has been married twice and has three children. His first marriage, to a woman named Gaëlle, ended in 2003. They have two sons. In 2003, he started dating his on-screen partner [[Alexandra Lamy]] of the comedy series ''[[Un gars, une fille (French TV series)|Un gars, une fille]]''; the two had originally met at the audition, and fell in love while shooting the series. They married in [[Anduze]] on 25 July 2009. In November 2013, it was announced that the couple had separated.{{cite web|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/tvshowbiz/article-2507042/Jean-Dujardin-announces-divorce-wife-years-Alaxandra-Lamy.html|title=Oscar-winner Jean Dujardin announces divorce from wife of four-years Alexandra Lamy|date=14 November 2013|work=Daily Mail|accessdate=14 November 2013}} He and the French [[ice dancer]] [[Nathalie Péchalat]] had a child, Jeanne, in December, 2015.{{cite web|title=NATHALIE PECHALAT AND JEAN DUJARDIN HAVE A BABY GIRL|url=http://www.closermag.fr/people/people-francais/info-closer-nathalie-pechalat-et-jean-dujardin-sont-parents-d-une-petite-fille-579467}} ==Filmography== ===Film=== {| class="wikitable sortable" |- ! Biggs) * 2016 : "Pour un pote" featuring [[Bigflo & Oli]] ==References== {{reflist|30em}} ==External links== {{Commons category|Jean Dujardin}} *{{IMDb name|241121}} *[http://www.english.rfi.fr/france/20120202-oscar-contender-dujardin-ad-campaign-controversy-new-film Oscar contender Dujardin in ad campaign controversy over new film on RFI English] {{Navboxes |title = Awards for Jean Dujardin |list = {{AcademyAwardBestActor 2001–2020}} {{AACTA International Award for Best Actor}} {{BAFTA Award for Best Actor 2000-2019}} {{Cabourg Film Festival Best Actor Award}} {{Prix d'interprétation masculine 2000–2019}} {{GoldenGlobeBestActorMotionPictureMusicalComedy 2001–2020}} {{IndependentSpiritBestMaleLead 2000-2020}} {{London Film Critics Circle Award for Actor of the Year}} {{ScreenActorsGuildAward MaleLeadMotionPicture 2001-2020}} }} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Dujardin, Jean}} [[Category:1972 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Best Actor Academy Award winners]] [[Category:Best Actor BAFTA Award winners]] [[Category:Best Actor AACTA International Award winners]] [[Category:Best Musical or Comedy Actor Golden Globe (film) winners]] [[Category:French male film actors]] [[Category:French comedians]] [[Category:French television directors]] [[Category:People from Rueil-Malmaison]] [[Category:French male television actors]] [[Category:20th-century French male actors]] [[Category:21st-century French male actors]] [[Category:Outstanding Performance by a Male Actor in a Leading Role Screen Actors Guild Award winners]] [[Category:Independent Spirit Award for Best Male Lead winners]] [[Category:French male screenwriters]]
